<<pre class="ocsforge_color odocwiki_code"|<<span class="ocsforge_color_keyword"|module>> <<span class="ocsforge_color_uid"|<<span class="ocsforge_color_uid"|Lwt_js_events>>>> <<span class="ocsforge_color_delimiter"|~:>> <<span class="ocsforge_color_keyword"|sig>><<a_api text=".." | module Lwt_js_events >><<span class="ocsforge_color_keyword"|end>>>>~Programming mouse or keyboard events handlers using ~Lwt

----

~Reminder~:
   ~Event capturing starts with the outer most element in the ~D~O~M and
   works inwards to the ~H~T~M~L element the event took place on ~(capture phase~)
   and then out again ~(bubbling phase~)~.


   ~Examples of use~:


   ~Waiting for a click on <<span class="odocwiki_inlinecode"|elt~1>> before continuing~:


   
<<code language='ocaml'|let%lwt _ = Lwt_js_events.click elt1 in>>



   ~Doing some operation for each value change in input element <<span class="odocwiki_inlinecode"|inp>>~:


   
<<code language='ocaml'|Lwt_js_events.(async (fun () ->
      clicks inp1 (fun ev _ -> ...)
   ))>>



   ~Defining a thread that waits for ~E~S~C key on an element~:


   
<<code language='ocaml'|let rec esc elt =
      let%lwt ev = keydown elt in
      if ev##.keyCode = 27
      then Lwt.return ev
      else esc elt>>



   ~Waiting for a click or escape key before continuing~:


   
<<code language='ocaml'|let%lwt () =
       Lwt.pick [(let%lwt _ = esc Dom_html.document in Lwt.return ());
                 (let%lwt _ = click Dom_html.document in Lwt.return ())]
     in ...>>

    execute handler~, and start again waiting for the event~. ~Events
